message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: E-Commerce Promotional Products Selection Using SWARA and TOPSIS
Paper Abstract: This research aims to select products that will be used for promotion on e-commerce platforms. The increasing use of e-commerce has led to a high level of competition in the e-commerce field. The company strives to maintain the quality of its services to increase customer satisfaction, one of which is by providing regular promotions. The process of selecting promotional products is a routine activity carried out every week. However, the current promotional product selection process is not effective enough, and there are no criteria to use as a reference for selection. This research was conducted on two e-commerce companies actively operating in Indonesia. The research began with a literature study and expert survey to select important criteria in selecting promotional products. Weighting of important criteria is carried out using the Stepwise Weight Assessment Ratio Analysis (SWARA) method. Finally, the Technique for Order of Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution (TOPSIS) method is used to rank the best products to promote. The results showed that products from Soundcore, Lenovo, and Xiaomi were the best products with preference values of 0.83, 0.65, and 0.60 respectively.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"TOPSIS - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TOPSIS"},{"title":"Multi-objective optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-objective_optimization"},{"title":"Preference ranking organization method for enrichment evaluation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Preference_Ranking_Organization_Method_for_Enrichment_Evaluation"},{"title":"Ordinal priority approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ordinal_priority_approach"},{"title":"Preference learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Preference_learning"},{"title":"Topological sorting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_sorting"},{"title":"Preference (economics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Preference_(economics)"},{"title":"Lexicographic preferences - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lexicographic_preferences"},{"title":"Topkis's theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topkis's_theorem"},{"title":"Preference elicitation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Preference_elicitation"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about TOPSIS:

The Technique for Order of Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution (TOPSIS) is a multi-criteria decision analysis method, which was originally developed by Ching-Lai Hwang and Yoon in 1981 with further developments by Yoon in 1987, and Hwang, Lai and Liu in 1993.

TOPSIS is a decision-making methodology used to rank and select alternatives based on multiple criteria. The method works by evaluating how close alternatives are to an ideal solution, making it useful for complex decision-making problems where multiple objectives need to be considered simultaneously.

The search results also mention that vector normalisation was incorporated with the original development of the TOPSIS method, which is a key computational step in the process.

If you'd like more specific information about the TOPSIS methodology, its steps, or how it's applied in particular domains, feel free to ask!

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Customer satisfaction"

Links: [{"title":"Customer satisfaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Customer_satisfaction"},{"title":"American Customer Satisfaction Index - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Customer_Satisfaction_Index"},{"title":"Kano model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kano_model"},{"title":"Customer success - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Customer_success"},{"title":"Press Ganey - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Press_Ganey"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Wikipedia Signpost/2010-07-26/In the news - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Wikipedia_Signpost/2010-07-26/In_the_news"}]

Here are the search results for "Customer satisfaction":

## Overview

Customer satisfaction is defined as "the number of customers, or percentage of total customers, whose reported experience with a firm, its products, or its services (ratings) exceeds specified satisfaction goals".(no content)Customer satisfaction is a term frequently used in marketing to evaluate customer experience, and it is a measure of how products and services supplied by a company meet or surpass customer expectation.

## Business Importance

Enhancing customer satisfaction and fostering customer loyalty are pivotal for businesses, given the significant importance of improving the balance between customer attitudes before and after the consumption process.(no content)In a competitive marketplace where businesses compete for customers, customer satisfaction is seen as a major differentiator and increasingly has become an important element of business strategy.

## Theoretical Frameworks

Expectancy disconfirmation theory is the most widely accepted theoretical framework for explaining customer satisfaction. Another important framework is the Kano model, a theory for product development and customer satisfaction developed in the 1980s by Noriaki Kano, which provides a framework for understanding how different features of a product or service impact customer satisfaction.

## Measurement and Metrics

The American Customer Satisfaction Index (ACSI) is an economic indicator that measures the satisfaction of consumers across the U.S. economy.(no content)The ACSI interviews about 350,000 customers annually and asks about their satisfaction with the goods and services they have purchased and consumed.

Web search results for query: "Product selection decision making"

Links: [{"title":"Consumer choice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumer_choice"},{"title":"Consideration set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consideration_set"},{"title":"Buyer decision process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buyer_decision_process"},{"title":"Decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision-making"},{"title":"Decision-matrix method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision-matrix_method"},{"title":"Product differentiation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differentiation_(economics)"},{"title":"Choice architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Choice_architecture"},{"title":"The Paradox of Choice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Paradox_of_Choice"},{"title":"Material selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Material_selection"},{"title":"Consumer confusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumer_confusion"}]

I've found comprehensive information on product selection decision-making. Here's an overview of the key topics from the search results:

## Consumer Decision-Making Process

The five stages of a decision process were first introduced by philosopher John Dewey in How We Think in 1910, with later studies expanding upon Dewey's initial work and being considered foundational for analysis of consumer purchasing decision-making.(no content)These stages include: Problem/Need Recognition, Information Search, Evaluation of Alternatives, Purchase Decision, and Post Purchase Behavior.

## Consideration Sets

Consideration set is a model used in consumer behaviour to represent all of the brands and products a consumer evaluates before making a final purchase decision.(no content)In this model, consumers screen many product options before fully evaluating just a few options (usually 2–5), which reduces the cognitive load and fatigue of an exhaustive search, with this screening process mostly based on heuristics about the product.

## Choice Overload

Choice overload occurs when the set of purchasing options becomes overwhelmingly large for a consumer, and research shows that it can lead to decision fatigue, where the cognitive effort required to choose from many options causes consumers to delay decisions or rely on convenience over preference.

## Decision-Making Biases

Consumers are influenced by emotional and nonrational considerations making attempts to be rational only partially successful.(no content)The distinction is made between maximizers (someone who needs to be assured their purchase was the best that could be made) and satisficers (who have criteria and standards but are not worried about the possibility that there might be something better).

The search results provide extensive information on consumer behavior, decision frameworks, and the various factors that influence product selection choices.

Links: [{"title":"Consumer choice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumer_choice"},{"title":"Consideration set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consideration_set"},{"title":"Buyer decision process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buyer_decision_process"},{"title":"Decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision-making"},{"title":"Decision-matrix method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision-matrix_method"},{"title":"Product differentiation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differentiation_(economics)"},{"title":"Choice architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Choice_architecture"},{"title":"The Paradox of Choice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Paradox_of_Choice"},{"title":"Material selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Material_selection"},{"title":"Consumer confusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumer_confusion"}]

I've found comprehensive information on product selection decision-making. Here's an overview of the key topics from the search results:

## Consumer Decision-Making Process

The five stages of a decision process were first introduced by philosopher John Dewey in How We Think in 1910, with later studies expanding upon Dewey's initial work and being considered foundational for analysis of consumer purchasing decision-making.(no content)These stages include: Problem/Need Recognition, Information Search, Evaluation of Alternatives, Purchase Decision, and Post Purchase Behavior.

## Consideration Sets

Consideration set is a model used in consumer behaviour to represent all of the brands and products a consumer evaluates before making a final purchase decision.(no content)In this model, consumers screen many product options before fully evaluating just a few options (usually 2–5), which reduces the cognitive load and fatigue of an exhaustive search, with this screening process mostly based on heuristics about the product.

## Choice Overload

Choice overload occurs when the set of purchasing options becomes overwhelmingly large for a consumer, and research shows that it can lead to decision fatigue, where the cognitive effort required to choose from many options causes consumers to delay decisions or rely on convenience over preference.

## Decision-Making Biases

Consumers are influenced by emotional and nonrational considerations making attempts to be rational only partially successful.(no content)The distinction is made between maximizers (someone who needs to be assured their purchase was the best that could be made) and satisficers (who have criteria and standards but are not worried about the possibility that there might be something better).

The search results provide extensive information on consumer behavior, decision frameworks, and the various factors that influence product selection choices.

Web search results for query: "Multi-criteria decision analysis MCDA"

Links: [{"title":"Multiple-criteria decision analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiple-criteria_decision_analysis"},{"title":"Multicriteria classification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multicriteria_classification"},{"title":"Decision matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision_matrix"},{"title":"ÉLECTRE - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%89LECTRE"},{"title":"Decision-making paradox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision-making_paradox"},{"title":"Decision EXpert - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision_EXpert"},{"title":"Decision analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision_analysis"},{"title":"Analytic network process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Analytic_network_process"},{"title":"European Working Group on Multiple Criteria Decision Aiding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Working_Group_on_Multiple_Criteria_Decision_Aiding"},{"title":"Applications of sensitivity analysis to multi-criteria decision making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_sensitivity_analysis_to_multi-criteria_decision_making"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis (MCDA):

## Definition and Purpose

MCDM or MCDA are acronyms for multiple-criteria decision-making and multiple-criteria decision analysis.(no content)MCDM is concerned with structuring and solving decision and planning problems involving multiple criteria. The purpose is to support decision-makers facing such problems.

## Key Characteristics

Typically, there does not exist a unique optimal solution for such problems and it is necessary to use decision-makers' preferences to differentiate between solutions.(no content)"Solving" could correspond to choosing the "best" alternative from a set of available alternatives or choosing a small set of good alternatives, or grouping alternatives into different preference sets.

## Common Methods

Several MCDA methods are widely used:

- **AHP (Analytic Hierarchy Process)**: The AHP first decomposes the decision problem into a hierarchy of subproblems. Then the decision-maker evaluates the relative importance of its various elements by pairwise comparisons. The AHP converts these evaluations to numerical values (weights or priorities), which are used to calculate a score for each alternative.

- **ÉLECTRE**: ÉLECTRE is a family of multi-criteria decision analysis (MCDA) methods that originated in Europe in the mid-1960s.

- **DEX (Decision EXpert)**: DEX (Decision EXpert) is a qualitative multi-criteria decision analysis (MCDA) method for decision making.

## History

MCDM has been an active area of research since the 1970s.

Here are the search results for "E-commerce electronic commerce":

## Definition

E-commerce (electronic commerce) refers to commercial activities including the electronic buying or selling products and services which are conducted on online platforms or over the Internet.

## Key Technologies

E-commerce draws on technologies such as mobile commerce, electronic funds transfer, supply chain management, Internet marketing, online transaction processing, electronic data interchange (EDI), inventory management systems, and automated data collection systems.

## Main Categories

There are three areas of e-commerce: online retailing, electronic markets, and online auctions. Additionally, the 6 types of business models that can be used in e-commerce include: Business-to-Consumer (B2C), Consumer-to-Business (C2B), Business-to-Business (B2B), Consumer-to-Consumer (C2C), Business-to-Administration (B2A), and Consumer-to-Administration.

## Types of Transactions

Typical e-commerce transactions include the purchase of products (such as books from Amazon) or services (such as music downloads in the form of digital distribution such as the iTunes Store).

## Modern Practices

E-commerce businesses may employ some or all of the following: Online shopping for retail sales direct to consumers via web sites and mobile apps, conversational commerce via live chat, chatbots, and voice assistants.

These search results provide comprehensive information about electronic commerce and its various aspects.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
